text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 8.7.14, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Administrative Appeal Cases.
Case Carding, due to the APS IRM restructure. (
) Revised IRM
, ATE Closing Procedures, for the Appeals Technical Employees (ATE) use the updated customized Form
FOIA in APGolf. (
) Revised IRM
, Closing Letter, for updated contact information on the Office of Governmental Information Services (OGIS). (
) Revised IRM
, ATM Closing Procedure, for the Appeals Team Manager (ATM) to that the ATEs use the updated customized Form
FOIA in APGolf. (
) Removed IRM
, FOIA Analysis and Feedback Record, as it is no longer required.
Revised IRM 8.7.14.14.3, ATM Closing Procedure, for the Appeals Team Manager (ATM) to that the ATEs use the updated customized Form 5402 FOIA in APGolf.
Removed IRM 8.7.14.15.2.1, FOIA Analysis and Feedback Record, as it is no longer required.
John V. Cardone Director, Policy, Quality and Case Support

Upon receipt of the FOIA administrative appeal case file from APS, the Appeals Team Manager (ATM) will:

a. Determine the appropriate grade of the case and assign it to an ATE b. Insure ACDS is updated for the CSC which includes the assigned ATE grade of the case. c. Access AFOIA and assign the case through AFOIA. d. Include the AFOIA documents in the case file and give to the assigned ATE. e. The ATM may also verify the timeliness of the Appeals Request per Treasury Regulations
(11-27-2013)AppealsTechnical EmployeesResponsibilities

business days) to determine whether the administrative appeal request is timely. If untimely, the ATE will send a closing letter to the requester and a copy to the Disclosure Manager of the Disclosure Specialist who worked the case previously. See IRM
Note: The ATM may have determined the request to be untimely; however, it is the ATE’s ultimate responsi- bility to determine if the request is timely. For Premature Referrals, See IRM

The standard Appeals Uniform Acknowledgement Letter procedures do not apply to FOIA cases. However, after receipt, per Treasury Regulations
)(iii), Appeals is required to send an acknowledgment letter to the requester including the date of receipt and the requirement to complete the consideration of the appeal within
business days after the date Appeals receives the request. The ATE should annotate in the Case Activity record that the required FOIA acknowledgement letter was sent. Due to the strict
business day time line to work a FOIA case, a combo acknowledgement/ closing letter is often issued explaining when the FOIA request was received and Appeals’ determination.

Appeals does not have jurisdiction to review late filed FOIA administrative appeal requests. A letter is sent informing the requester that the appeal was late and copy to the Disclosure Manager of the Disclosure Specialist who nally worked the request. The letter should include the following information:

Note: This time excludes Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays.
(2) The regular time frame for making a determination on a FOIA case can be extended by 10 days and applies if one or more of the following unusual cir-
extended by

days and applies if one or more of the following unusual cumstances apply: a. The need to search for and collect the requested records from field ties or other establishments that are separate from the office the request; b. The need to search for, collect, and appropriately examine a amount of separate and distinct records which are demanded in a request; c. The need for consultation, which shall be conducted with all speed, with another agency having a substantial interest in the tion of the request or among two or more constituent units of the Department of the Treasury having substantial subject matter interest therein; and d. The need for consultation with business submitters to determine the nature and extent of proprietary information. Note: A business submitter is one who submits business information to the Business information is any trade secret or other confidential financial or commercial (including research) information. (
) A written notice to the requester is required for a
day deadline This notice will include both: (cid:

), if the IRS Appeals fails to within the time frame prescribed, the requester has deemed to have all administrative remedies and may file suit in court. (

) If a requester files suit after the prescribed time frame for Appeals to work case, Appeals sends a letter to the requester stating that the case is being closed because the requester has filed suit in court. Appeals will close the case sustaining Disclosure’s determination and use the closing code

) If Appeals fails to comply within the prescribed time frame, the requester commence an action in the United States District Court in the jurisdiction in which the requester resides, in which the requester’s principal place of business is located, in which the records are situated, or in the District of Columbia in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure (
App) applicable to actions against an agency of the United States. Internal Revenue Manual

) The FOIA requires agencies to make the maximum possible information available to the public. The decision to edit or withhold records is generally Exemptions made based upon the application of nine specific exemptions. These exemptions are listed in
USC
(b) and form the legal basis for the IRS withhold records or portions of records from the public. Careful

If a timely appeal is made and the request does not meet the requirements as outlined in IRM 8.7.14.8 , the requester must submit a perfected administrative appeal request within 35 days from the date of communication from the

The FOIA requires agencies to make the maximum possible information available to the public. The decision to edit or withhold records is generally made based upon the application of nine specific exemptions. These specific exemptions are listed in
USC
(b) and form the legal basis for the IRS to withhold records or portions of records from the public. Careful consideration of the exemptions is required when reviewing responsive records.

The FOIA requires agencies to make the maximum possible information available to the public. The decision to edit or withhold records is generally made based upon the application of nine specific exemptions. These specific exemptions are listed in 5 USC 552(b) and form the legal basis for the IRS to withhold records or portions of records from the public. Careful consideration the exemptions is required when reviewing responsive records.

(2) related solely to the internal personnel rules and practices of an agency;
specifically exempted from disclosure by statute (other than section

b of this title), if that statute - requires that the matters be withheld from the public in such a manner as to leave no discretion the issue; or establishes particular criteria for withholding or refers to particular types of matters to be withheld; enacted after the date of enactment of the OPEN FOIA Act of
, specifically cites to this
(4) trade secrets and commercial or financial information obtained from a person and privileged or dential;
(5) inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency;
(6) personnel and medical files and similar files the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly un- warranted invasion of personal privacy;

(7) records or information compiled for law enforcement purposes, but only to the extent that the pro- duction of such law enforcement records or information (A) could reasonably be expected to interfere with enforcement proceedings, (B) would deprive a person of a right to a fair trial or an impartial adjudi- cation, (C) could reasonably be expected to constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, (D) could reasonably be expected to disclose the identity of a confidential source, including a State, local,

(7) records or information compiled for law enforcement purposes, but only to the extent that the pro- duction of such law enforcement records or information (A) could reasonably be expected to interfere with enforcement proceedings, (B) would deprive a person of a right to a fair trial or an impartial cation, (C) could reasonably be expected to constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, could reasonably be expected to disclose the identity of a confidential source, including a State, local, or foreign agency or authority or any private institution which furnished information on a confidential basis, and, in the case of a record or information compiled by criminal law enforcement authority in course of a criminal investigation or by an agency conducting a lawful national security intelligence in- vestigation, information furnished by a confidential source, (E) would disclose techniques and procedures for law enforcement investigations or prosecutions, or would disclose guidelines for law forcement investigations or prosecutions if such disclosure could reasonably be expected to risk circumvention of the law, or (F) could reasonably be expected to endanger the life or physical safety any individual;

(8) contained in or related to examination, operating, or condition reports prepared by, on behalf of, or for the use of an agency responsible for the regulation or supervision of financial institutions; or

(9) geological and geophysical information and data, including maps, concerning wells. Any reasonably segregate portion of a record shall be provided to any person requesting such record after deletion of the portions which are exempt under this subsection. The amount of information deleted, and the exemption under which the deletion is made, shall be indicated on the released portion of the record, unless including that indication would harm an interest protected by the exemption in this subsection under which the deletion is made. If technically feasible, the amount of the information deleted, and exemption under which the deletion is made, shall be indicated at the place in the record where such deletion is made.

After the ATE makes a determination on the administrative appeal and submits the case to the Appeals Team Manager for review and approval, the closing letter is signed by the Appeals Team Manager. A copy of the closing letter is sent to the requestor, to the Disclosure Manager of the Specialist that worked the original case, and to the designated Management and Program Analyst from HQ Disclosure Office. The Appeals Team Manager also sends a copy of the Form
, Appeals Case Memorandum (ACM), and the closing letter to the designated Management and Program Analyst from HQ Disclosure Office. The case is then forwarded to APS for closing.
of Information Act (FOIA) Appeal Cases 8.7.14
Only the following closing codes are used for FOIA cases:

Closing Code FOIA Closing Code Definition 14 Fully Sustained - Appeals denied the request in full (i.e., the finding in the adverse determination letter was fully sustained) 15 Not Sustained - Appeals granted the request in full (i.e. the finding in the adverse determination letter was reversed in full) 16 Part Sustained - (cid:129) Appeals granted the request in part or (cid:129) FOIA request withdrawn by the requester 20 Premature Referral
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
Technical and Procedural (

) After Appeals reviews all documents and ensures an adequate search for documents was done, a determination is made. If Appeals determines that Search adequate search was not done, Appeals will discuss with Disclosure that additional search is required. If Disclosure does not agree with the search, Appeals will issue a letter signed by the Appeals Team Manager to Disclosure Manager of the Disclosure Specialist or other applicable govern- ment agency along with the requester indicating that an additional search is required. (

) If Appeals receives a FOIA administrative appeal request while the Office is working the request and an initial determination has not been Referral Appeals will close the request as a premature referral. Appeals will respond the requester advising him/her that there are no administrative appeal and if the requester is not willing to wait for an initial determination, the recourse is to seek judicial review in court. a. The assigned ATE will send a copy of the closing letter to the Manager of the Disclosure Specialist who originally worked the b. The ATE will use the closing code

page 11 Item Description Number 3 Summary of determination in denial letter or adverse determination letter 4 What is requested in appeal 5 Appeals determination in case (cid:129) Reason for determination (cid:129) Volume of documents, if applicable 6 If the case result is “not full grant” insert the following statement regarding the availability of mediation through the Office of Government Information Services:Aspartof the 2007 FOIA amendments, the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) was created to offer mediation services to resolve disputes between FOIA requesters and the Office of Disclosure as a non- exclusive alternative to litigation. The Office of Appeals is not a part of this mediation process. Using OGIS services does not affect your right to pursue litigation. If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974. If you disagree with the Appeals determination and wish to pursue mediation, you may contact OGIS in any of the following ways: Office of Government Information Services National Archives and Records Administration 8601 Adelphi Road - OGIS College Park, MD 20740 E-mail: ogis@nara.gov Web: https://ogis.archives.gov Telephone: 202-741-5770 Facsimile: 202-741-5769 Toll-free: 1-877-684-6448 7 Statement of judicial remedies (3) The person delegated to sign the Appeals determination letter is the Appeals Team Manager or designate.
If it is determined that the request should be partially or fully granted, the and the Disclosure Specialist will discuss the documents to be released.

8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines

) The AFOIA Project is one initiative in the Modernized Business Products and Processes Strategy to update and modernize Disclosure operations. AFOIA is of the document management system used by the Office of Disclosure. AFOIA System focuses on using technology and developing national standards to improve quality and efficiency of Disclosure casework and program processing. AFOIA will enhance employee work life, eliminate burden, and fully use employees’ disclosure technical knowledge and expertise. (
) AFOIA improves the quality, accuracy, and timeliness of responses to requests for information through ready access to shared corporate data. (

) AFOIA is a powerful image-based document management system. The name comes from its original design to automate Freedom of Information Act case processing. However, AFOIA was changed to capture scanned images and data for all Disclosure casework as well as provide administrative for other Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (GLD) programs including ernmental Liaison activities, daily time tracking and generation of reports for workplan monitoring. In addition, AFOIA is used by Safeguards and Appeals. (

) ATMs and ATEs use and access AFOIA to retrieve responsive documents, respondence from Disclosure, and to record and save Appeals’ determination on administratively appealed cases onto the AFOIA system. Note: The ATMs and ATEs still work and close AFOIA cases through Appeals

The AFOIA Project is one initiative in the Modernized Business Products and Processes Strategy to update and modernize Disclosure operations. AFOIA is the document management system used by the Office of Disclosure. AFOIA focuses on using technology and developing national standards to improve the quality and efficiency of Disclosure casework and program processing. AFOIA will enhance employee work life, eliminate burden, and fully use employees’ disclosure technical knowledge and expertise.
AFOIA improves the quality, accuracy, and timeliness of responses to customer requests for information through ready access to shared corporate data.

ATMs and ATEs use and access AFOIA to retrieve responsive documents, respondence from Disclosure, and to record and save Appeals’ determination on administratively appealed cases onto the AFOIA system.
Note: The ATMs and ATEs still work and close AFOIA cases through Appeals Cen- tralized Database System (ACDS).
